title: Bob Veselic
text:
Robert Michael Veselic (September 27, 1955 – December 26, 1995) was an American <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="baseball%20player">player</a>. The <a href="right-handed">right-handed</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> appeared in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> in six <a href="games%20pitched">games</a> and 26 <a href="inning%20%28baseball%29">innings</a>, all in <a href="relief%20pitcher">relief</a>, for the – <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a>. He was listed at tall and .
Veselic was native of <a href="Pittsburgh%2C%20Pennsylvania">Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania</a>, but attended <a href="Alameda%20High%20School">Alameda High School</a> in the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Bay%20Area">San Francisco Bay Area</a>. He was selected by Minnesota in the first round of the <a href="1976%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20Draft">1976 Major League Baseball Draft</a> out of <a href="Mount%20San%20Antonio%20College">Mount San Antonio College</a>. A <a href="starting%20pitcher">starting pitcher</a> in <a href="minor%20league%20baseball">minor league baseball</a>, he <a href="win%20%28baseball%29">won</a> 18 games (losing eight) in his second pro season, spent with the 1978 <a href="Visalia%20Oaks">Visalia Oaks</a> of the Class A <a href="California%20League">California League</a>.
Veselic made his MLB debut on September 18, 1980, in relief of <a href="Pete%20Redfern">Pete Redfern</a> in a 5–0 loss to the <a href="Milwaukee%20Brewers">Milwaukee Brewers</a>. After spending 1981 with the <a href="Triple-A%20%28baseball%29">Triple-A</a> <a href="Toledo%20Mud%20Hens">Toledo Mud Hens</a>, Veselic again joined the Twins in September and worked in five games. On September 13 at <a href="Metropolitan%20Stadium">Metropolitan Stadium</a>, he relieved starter <a href="Don%20Cooper">Don Cooper</a> in the sixth inning with the Twins trailing the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a>, 4–2. After allowing one inherited runner to score on a <a href="sacrifice%20fly">sacrifice fly</a>, he gave up only one more <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">run</a> the rest of the way, and the Twins rallied to win the game, 7–6, for Veselic's only Major League victory. (Ironically, Cooper later became the White Sox' longtime <a href="coach%20%28baseball%29">pitching coach</a>.)
Veselic returned to the minors in 1982 and finished his career after the 1983 season. He died from <a href="cancer">cancer</a> at the age of 40 in <a href="Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Los Angeles</a>.
